dictionary.definition: written and sent with love and care. (The initialism is sometimes written on love letters. Also an acronym.) _ All her letters come SWAK.  I know they are sealed with a kiss, because she says so.

dictionary.phrase: see eye to eye (about someone or something) (with someone)
dictionary.definition: [for someone] to agree about someone or something with someone else.  I’m glad we see eye to eye about Todd with Mary.  I see eye to eye with Mary. Will labor and management ever see eye to eye on the new contract?

dictionary.phrase: see eye to eye (on someone or something) (with someone)
dictionary.definition: [for someone] to agree about someone or something with someone else.  I’m glad we see eye to eye about Todd with Mary.  I see eye to eye with Mary. Will labor and management ever see eye to eye on the new contract?

dictionary.phrase: see no further than the end of one’s nose
dictionary.definition: to be narrow-minded; to lack understanding and perception.  She is so selfish she can see no further than the end of her nose.  You don’t care about anyone but yourself. You can’t see any further than the end of your nose.

dictionary.phrase: cannot see (any) further than the end of one’s nose
dictionary.definition: to be narrow-minded; to lack understanding and perception.  She is so selfish she can see no further than the end of her nose.  You don’t care about anyone but yourself. You can’t see any further than the end of your nose.

dictionary.phrase: can’t see beyond the end of one’s nose
dictionary.definition: to be narrow-minded; to lack understanding and perception.  She is so selfish she can see no further than the end of her nose.  You don’t care about anyone but yourself. You can’t see any further than the end of your nose.
not to think of any objection to something.  I see no objection to your idea.  Do you see any objection? _ I do not see any objection to anything you have done.
not to think of any objection to something.  I see no objection to your idea.  Do you see any objection? _ I do not see any objection to anything you have done.

to usher or accompany someone into something or some place.  Please see her into the room and make sure she is seated where she can hear the speaker.  Please see in the speaker and make sure she finds her seat on the stage.

to usher or accompany someone into something or some place.  Please see her into the room and make sure she is seated where she can hear the speaker.  Please see in the speaker and make sure she finds her seat on the stage.
to accompany or escort someone out of something or some place. Please see our guest out of the factory.  Please show our guest out.
to accompany or escort someone out of something or some place. Please see our guest out of the factory.  Please show our guest out.
Inf. Good-bye. (Sometimes the reply is After while(, crocodile.)) _ Bob: See you later, alligator. Jane: After while, crocodile.  Bob: Bye, Tom. Tom: See you later, alligator. Bob: Later.
Inf. Good-bye. (Sometimes the reply is After while(, crocodile.)) _ Bob: See you later, alligator. Jane: After while, crocodile.  Bob: Bye, Tom. Tom: See you later, alligator. Bob: Later.

intoxicated; recovering from a drinking bout; having the delirium tremens.  When I got to the point of seeing pink elephants, I knew that something had to be done.  The old one who’s shaking—he’s probably seeing snakes.

intoxicated; recovering from a drinking bout; having the delirium tremens.  When I got to the point of seeing pink elephants, I knew that something had to be done.  The old one who’s shaking—he’s probably seeing snakes.

to separate someone from someone else or something from something else.  I was asked to segregate the swimmers from the nonswimmers.  Let’s segregate the larger fish from the smaller ones.
to separate someone from someone else or something from something else.  I was asked to segregate the swimmers from the nonswimmers.  Let’s segregate the larger fish from the smaller ones.

to betray someone; to reveal damaging information about someone.  Bill told everything he knew about Bob, and that sold Bob down the river.  You’ll be sorry if you sell me out.  Lefty sold out his friends, and we’ll all soon be arrested.

to betray someone; to reveal damaging information about someone.  Bill told everything he knew about Bob, and that sold Bob down the river.  You’ll be sorry if you sell me out.  Lefty sold out his friends, and we’ll all soon be arrested.
to liquidate all one’s assets in order to raise money to invest in something.  It’s a risky proposition. I wouldn’t bet the farm on it.
to liquidate all one’s assets in order to raise money to invest in something.  It’s a risky proposition. I wouldn’t bet the farm on it.

to dispatch an order for something to a company or other body making a public offer of goods. I sent in for a new product that is supposed to make my hair grow back. Did you send in for that country-and-western CD as you said you would? _ I sent off for the proper contest entry forms.

to dispatch an order for something to a company or other body making a public offer of goods. I sent in for a new product that is supposed to make my hair grow back. Did you send in for that country-and-western CD as you said you would? _ I sent off for the proper contest entry forms.
to make someone go into something or some place. George sent me into the house for a hammer.  The boys know where it is. He should have sent in the boys.  George sent me in.
to make someone go into something or some place. George sent me into the house for a hammer.  The boys know where it is. He should have sent in the boys.  George sent me in.
to order someone to leave something or some place. The teacher sent the student out of the room. The teacher sent out the troublesome students.
to order someone to leave something or some place. The teacher sent the student out of the room. The teacher sent out the troublesome students.
to order someone to go to some place. I sent Dave over to the main office.  Please send over someone else.
to order someone to go to some place. I sent Dave over to the main office.  Please send over someone else.

to order a player from the playing field, thus ending the player’s participation for the day.  The coach had sent four players to the showers before the end of the game.  He was angry enough to send them all to the locker room.

dictionary.phrase: send someone to the locker room
dictionary.definition: to order a player from the playing field, thus ending the player’s participation for the day.  The coach had sent four players to the showers before the end of the game.  He was angry enough to send them all to the locker room.
to dispatch something, such as an order, to a company or other body making a public offer of goods.  I sent the order in to the home office.  I sent in the order.
to dispatch something, such as an order, to a company or other body making a public offer of goods.  I sent the order in to the home office.  I sent in the order.
to segregate people or things. The nurse separated the infected people from the healthy ones.  Please separate the spoiled apples from the good ones.
to segregate people or things. The nurse separated the infected people from the healthy ones.  Please separate the spoiled apples from the good ones.
to remove something from something.  Frank separated the cream off from the milk. Separate off the hens from the rooster.
to remove something from something.  Frank separated the cream off from the milk. Separate off the hens from the rooster.
to remove something out from something.  She used a filter to separate the dirt particles out of the water.  A filter separated out the impurities.
to remove something out from something.  She used a filter to separate the dirt particles out of the water.  A filter separated out the impurities.

dictionary.phrase: separate the men from the boys
dictionary.definition: to separate the competent from those who are less competent. (Not necessarily just about males.) _ This is the kind of task that separates the men from the boys.  Working in a challenging place like this really separates the sheep from the goats.

dictionary.phrase: separate the sheep from the goats
dictionary.definition: to separate the competent from those who are less competent. (Not necessarily just about males.) _ This is the kind of task that separates the men from the boys.  Working in a challenging place like this really separates the sheep from the goats.

dictionary.phrase: set eyes on someone or something
dictionary.definition: to see someone or something for the first time.  I knew when I set eyes on that car that it was the car for me.  Have you ever laid eyes on such a beautiful f lower?

dictionary.phrase: lay eyes on someone or something
dictionary.definition: to see someone or something for the first time.  I knew when I set eyes on that car that it was the car for me.  Have you ever laid eyes on such a beautiful f lower?

dictionary.phrase: set fire to someone or something
dictionary.definition: to ignite someone or something; to put someone or something to flames.  The thief set fire to the building.  The poor man accidentally set himself on fire.

dictionary.phrase: set someone or something on fire
dictionary.definition: to ignite someone or something; to put someone or something to flames.  The thief set fire to the building.  The poor man accidentally set himself on fire.
to start out on something, such as a journey.  We intend to set forth on our journey very early in the morning. What time will you launch forth on your trip?
to start out on something, such as a journey.  We intend to set forth on our journey very early in the morning. What time will you launch forth on your trip?
to reestablish someone; to help someone become active and productive again. Gary’s uncle helped set him back on his feet.  We will all help set you on your feet again.

dictionary.phrase: set one on one’s feet again
dictionary.definition: to reestablish someone; to help someone become active and productive again. Gary’s uncle helped set him back on his feet.  We will all help set you on your feet again.
to lower or set down someone or something.  Put me down! _ Please set that vase down. It cost a fortune.  Put down that gun!
to lower or set down someone or something.  Put me down! _ Please set that vase down. It cost a fortune.  Put down that gun!

to set something, like a timepiece, to a lower number. (Put is less common.) _ It’s that time of year when you must set your clocks and watches back! _ Set back your clock tonight.  I have to put all the clocks back.

to set something, like a timepiece, to a lower number. (Put is less common.) _ It’s that time of year when you must set your clocks and watches back! _ Set back your clock tonight.  I have to put all the clocks back.

dictionary.phrase: set something back from something else
dictionary.definition: to place something at some distance from something else.  Set the glasses back from the edge or they will set something before someone, something, or some 598 get knocked off.  You should set back the crystal vase a little. It’s too close to the edge.

to place something at some distance from something else.  Set the glasses back from the edge or they will set something before someone, something, or some 598 get knocked off.  You should set back the crystal vase a little. It’s too close to the edge.

1. to place something on the surface of something.  Andy set the hot skillet down on the dishcloth and burned a hole in it.  He set down the skillet here and burned the counter. 2. to write something on paper.  Let me put this down on paper so we will have a record of what was said. I will set down this note on paper. 3. to land an aircraft. The pilot put the plane down exactly on time.  I can’t set down this plane in the fog.

1. to place something on the surface of something.  Andy set the hot skillet down on the dishcloth and burned a hole in it.  He set down the skillet here and burned the counter. 2. to write something on paper.  Let me put this down on paper so we will have a record of what was said. I will set down this note on paper. 3. to land an aircraft. The pilot put the plane down exactly on time.  I can’t set down this plane in the fog.
to install something into its place.  The movers set the stove into creature its proper place, and the plumber hooked it up two days later.  They set in the stove carefully.
to install something into its place.  The movers set the stove into creature its proper place, and the plumber hooked it up two days later.  They set in the stove carefully.

to correct something; to alter a situation to make it more fair.  This is a very unfortunate situation. I’ll ask the people responsible to set this matter right.  I’m sorry that we overcharged you. We’ll try to put it right.  I know I owe you some money, but don’t worry, I’ll make it good.

to figure out and correct something; to straighten out a mess.  I am sorry for the error. I am sure we can set it straight.  We’ll put this matter straight in a short time.
to figure out and correct something; to straighten out a mess.  I am sorry for the error. I am sure we can set it straight.  We’ll put this matter straight in a short time.
to clear up a problem with someone; to get even with someone.  John wants to settle a score with his neighbor.  Tom, it’s time you and I settled the score.
to clear up a problem with someone; to get even with someone.  John wants to settle a score with his neighbor.  Tom, it’s time you and I settled the score.

someone or something that is not as strong, healthy, full, or lively as before. (*Typically: be ~; become ~.) _ The sick man was a shadow of his former self.  The abandoned mansion was merely a shadow of its old self.

someone or something that is not as strong, healthy, full, or lively as before. (*Typically: be ~; become ~.) _ The sick man was a shadow of his former self.  The abandoned mansion was merely a shadow of its old self.

an untrustworthy person; a person who makes people suspicious.  There is a suspicious character lurking about in the hallway. Please call the police.
an untrustworthy person; a person who makes people suspicious.  There is a suspicious character lurking about in the hallway. Please call the police.

to take someone’s hand and move it up and down to greet someone or mark an agreement with someone. David shook my hand when he greeted me.  Anne and John shook hands before their business appointment.

to take someone’s hand and move it up and down to greet someone or mark an agreement with someone. David shook my hand when he greeted me.  Anne and John shook hands before their business appointment.
to be afraid; to shake from fear.  I was shaking in my boots because I had to go see the manager for being late.  Stop quaking in your boots, Bob. I’m not going to fire you.

to shed false tears; to pretend that one is weeping.  The child wasn’t really hurt, but she shed crocodile tears anyway. He thought he could get his way if he cried crocodile tears.
to shed false tears; to pretend that one is weeping.  The child wasn’t really hurt, but she shed crocodile tears anyway. He thought he could get his way if he cried crocodile tears.
to reveal something about something; to clarify something. (Also with any.) _ This discussion has shed some light on the problem.  Let’s see if Ann can throw any light on this question.
to reveal something about something; to clarify something. (Also with any.) _ This discussion has shed some light on the problem.  Let’s see if Ann can throw any light on this question.

to get along by oneself; to support oneself.  I’m sorry, I can’t pay your rent anymore. You’ll just have to shift for yourself.  When I became twenty years old, I left home and began to fend for myself.

to fire a gun in or at a place, usually at people.  The cowboy walked into the saloon and began to shoot the place up.  They shot up the place.
to fire a gun in or at a place, usually at people.  The cowboy walked into the saloon and began to shoot the place up.  They shot up the place.
Sl. to empty one’s stomach; to vomit.  I think I’m gonna shoot my cookies.  I shot my supper, and I was glad to get rid of it.

Inf. to chat and gossip. (The same as throw the bull. Use caution with crap, shit.) _Let’s get together sometime and shoot the bull. You spend too much time shooting the crap.

1. Fig. [of an argument that is] demolished or comprehensively destroyed. Come on, that theory was shot full of holes ages ago.  Your argument is all shot to hell. 2. to be very intoxicated due to drink or drugs. Tipsy? Shot to ribbons, more like! _Boy, I really felt shot full of holes. I’ll never drink another drop. 3. totally ruined. (Use hell with caution.) _My car is all shot to hell and can’t be depended on. This rusty old knife is shot to hell. I need a sharper one.

dictionary.phrase: shove someone or something down someone’s throat
dictionary.definition: to force someone to swallow something.  The harsh nurse forced the medicine down the patient’s throat.  The zookeepers rammed the food down the python’s throat.

dictionary.phrase: ram someone or something down someone’s throat
dictionary.definition: to force someone to swallow something.  The harsh nurse forced the medicine down the patient’s throat.  The zookeepers rammed the food down the python’s throat.

dictionary.phrase: force someone or something down someone’s throat
dictionary.definition: to force someone to swallow something.  The harsh nurse forced the medicine down the patient’s throat.  The zookeepers rammed the food down the python’s throat.

to act in an angry or threatening manner. (Alludes to what an angry wolf or dog does.) _We thought Bob was meek and mild, but he really showed his teeth when Jack insulted his girlfriend.  The enemy forces didn’t expect the country they invaded to bare its teeth.

to act in an angry or threatening manner. (Alludes to what an angry wolf or dog does.) _We thought Bob was meek and mild, but he really showed his teeth when Jack insulted his girlfriend.  The enemy forces didn’t expect the country they invaded to bare its teeth.

to lead or usher someone into somewhere.  The butler showed me into the sitting room and asked me to wait.  The car dealer showed me into the sales office and asked me to sign some papers.  The butler showed in the guests one by one.

to lead or usher someone into somewhere.  The butler showed me into the sitting room and asked me to wait.  The car dealer showed me into the sales office and asked me to sign some papers.  The butler showed in the guests one by one.
to lead or direct someone to a place to sit. May I show you to your seat, sir? _The ushers showed us to our seats politely and efficiently.
to lead or direct someone to a place to sit. May I show you to your seat, sir? _The ushers showed us to our seats politely and efficiently.
to lead or take someone to the door or exit. After we finished our talk, she showed me to the door.  Bill and I finished our chat as he saw me to the door.
to lead or take someone to the door or exit. After we finished our talk, she showed me to the door.  Bill and I finished our chat as he saw me to the door.

to ignore something unpleasant or offensive as if it meant something else. She shrugged off the criticism as harmless. I passed off the remark as misinformed.  Bill scolded me, but I just passed it off.

to ignore something unpleasant or offensive as if it meant something else. She shrugged off the criticism as harmless. I passed off the remark as misinformed.  Bill scolded me, but I just passed it off.

dictionary.phrase: Shut the stable door after the horse has bolted.
dictionary.definition: Prov. To try to prevent something that has already happened; to act too late. When Ray heard that the bank had failed, he tried to withdraw his money, but there was no money to withdraw. He was shutting the stable door after the horse had bolted. Jenny has stopped smoking since the doctor told her that her lungs were in bad shape, but I’m afraid she’s locking the stable door after the horse is stolen.

dictionary.phrase: Lock the stable door after the horse is stolen.
dictionary.definition: Prov. To try to prevent something that has already happened; to act too late. When Ray heard that the bank had failed, he tried to withdraw his money, but there was no money to withdraw. He was shutting the stable door after the horse had bolted. Jenny has stopped smoking since the doctor told her that her lungs were in bad shape, but I’m afraid she’s locking the stable door after the horse is stolen.
Inf. Shut up!; Shut your mouth! _ I’ve heard enough! Shut your cake hole!

dictionary.phrase: Shut your pie hole! Shut your face!
dictionary.definition: Inf. Shut up!; Shut your mouth! _ I’ve heard enough! Shut your cake hole!

dictionary.phrase: shuttle someone or something from person to person
dictionary.definition: (Specific persons or places are sometimes expressed.) to move or pass someone or something from person to person; to move or pass someone or something from place to place. My phone call was shuttled from person to person.  Mary shuttled her children from home to school to practice.

dictionary.phrase: shuttle someone or something from place to place
dictionary.definition: (Specific persons or places are sometimes expressed.) to move or pass someone or something from person to person; to move or pass someone or something from place to place. My phone call was shuttled from person to person.  Mary shuttled her children from home to school to practice.
to get rid of something in something else by sifting.  Dan sifted the impurities out of the f lour. Walter sifted out the foreign matter.
to get rid of something in something else by sifting.  Dan sifted the impurities out of the f lour. Walter sifted out the foreign matter.

dictionary.phrase: sign someone out of some place
dictionary.definition: to make a record of someone’s departure from some place.  Did someone sign you out of the factory, or did you just open the door and leave? _ I signed out those two who just left.
to make a record of someone’s departure from some place.  Did someone sign you out of the factory, or did you just open the door and leave? _ I signed out those two who just left.

dictionary.phrase: sign something out of some place
dictionary.definition: to make a record of the borrowing of something from some place.  Dave signed the tape recorder out of the library. Dave signed out the tape recorder as well as some blank tapes.
to make a record of the borrowing of something from some place.  Dave signed the tape recorder out of the library. Dave signed out the tape recorder as well as some blank tapes.

completely silent. (Has ominous connotations because of the reference to death. Usually used to promise someone that you will be silent and therefore not betray a secret. *Also: as ~.) _I knew something was wrong as soon as I entered the classroom; everyone was silent as the dead.  Jessica is as silent as the grave on the subject of her first marriage.  If you tell me what Katy said about me, I promise to be as silent as the grave.

completely silent. (Has ominous connotations because of the reference to death. Jessica is as silent as the grave on the subject of her first marriage.  If you tell me what Katy said about me, I promise to be as silent as the grave.

to change one’s manner, usually from bad to good. (Almost the same as dance to another tune.) _When she learned that I was a bank director, she began to sing a different tune.  You will sing another tune as soon as you find out how right I am!

to change one’s manner, usually from bad to good. (Almost the same as dance to another tune.) _When she learned that I was a bank director, she began to sing a different tune.  You will sing another tune as soon as you find out how right I am!

dictionary.phrase: Sing before breakfast, you’ll cry before night.
dictionary.definition: Prov. If you wake up feeling very happy, your mood will change before the end of the day.  Jill: I woke up in such a good mood today. I don’t even know why, but everything seems good. Jane: Sing before breakfast, you’ll cry before night. Alan: Good morning, dear! Isn’t it a wonderful day? I feel great. Jane: Sing before breakfast, you’ll cry before supper.

dictionary.phrase: Sing before breakfast, you’ll cry before supper.
dictionary.definition: Prov. If you wake up feeling very happy, your mood will change before the end of the day.  Jill: I woke up in such a good mood today. I don’t even know why, but everything seems good. Jane: Sing before breakfast, you’ll cry before night. Alan: Good morning, dear! Isn’t it a wonderful day? I feel great. Jane: Sing before breakfast, you’ll cry before supper.
to praise someone highly and enthusiastically.  The boss is singing his new secretary’s praises.  The theater critics are singing the praises of the young actor.

dictionary.phrase: sing the praises of someone or something
dictionary.definition: to praise someone highly and enthusiastically.  The boss is singing his new secretary’s praises.  The theater critics are singing the praises of the young actor.

dictionary.phrase: sink something in(to) someone or something
dictionary.definition: to drive or push something into someone or something. The brave hero sank the wooden stake into the vampire. The hero sank in the stake.
to drive or push something into someone or something. The brave hero sank the wooden stake into the vampire. The hero sank in the stake.
to remain close, doing nothing to help. I do not intend to stand idly by while my children need my help. The wealthy man sat idly by while the poor people starved.
to remain close, doing nothing to help. I do not intend to stand idly by while my children need my help. The wealthy man sat idly by while the poor people starved.
[for an audience] to refuse to applaud.  The performance was really quite good, but the audience sat on its hands.  They sat on their hands during the first act.
[for an audience] to refuse to applaud.  The performance was really quite good, but the audience sat on its hands.  They sat on their hands during the first act.
to scoop something off the surface of something. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _ The cook skimmed the fat off the stew.  The cook skimmed off the fat.
to scoop something off the surface of something. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _ The cook skimmed the fat off the stew.  The cook skimmed off the fat.
to release the pressure or tension on something.  Slack up on the rope a bit, will you? _ Please slack off!
to release the pressure or tension on something.  Slack up on the rope a bit, will you? _ Please slack off!

dictionary.phrase: slant something toward someone or something
dictionary.definition: to bias something toward someone or something; to twist information so it favors someone or something.  The writer slanted the story toward the plaintiff ’s charges.  The reporter slanted her story in favor of one political party.

dictionary.phrase: slant something in favor of someone or something
dictionary.definition: to bias something toward someone or something; to twist information so it favors someone or something.  The writer slanted the story toward the plaintiff ’s charges.  The reporter slanted her story in favor of one political party.

to strike someone’s wrist with the open hand, as a punishment.  Aunt Maude slapped Tony on the wrist when he grabbed a couple of her freshly baked cookies. Tony was slapped on the wrist when he tried to swipe some cookies.

to strike someone’s wrist with the open hand, as a punishment.  Aunt Maude slapped Tony on the wrist when he grabbed a couple of her freshly baked cookies. Tony was slapped on the wrist when he tried to swipe some cookies.

dictionary.phrase: slap something onto someone or something
dictionary.definition: to place something onto someone or something by slapping. Tim slapped a sign onto Gary that said “kick me.” _ Tim came up to Gary’s back and slapped on a sign.
to place something onto someone or something by slapping. Tim slapped a sign onto Gary that said “kick me.” _ Tim came up to Gary’s back and slapped on a sign.
to sleep very soundly.  Everyone in our family sleeps like a log, so no one heard the thunderstorm in the middle of the night.  Nothing can wake me up. I usually sleep like a baby.
to sleep very soundly.  Everyone in our family sleeps like a log, so no one heard the thunderstorm in the middle of the night.  Nothing can wake me up. I usually sleep like a baby.
to insert something into something effortlessly. Henry slid the end of the seat-belt buckle into its holder and started the car.  Slide in the buckle and make sure it’s tight.
to insert something into something effortlessly. Henry slid the end of the seat-belt buckle into its holder and started the car.  Slide in the buckle and make sure it’s tight.
to cause something to slip or glide out of something without much effort. The hunter slid his knife out of its sheath and got ready to skin the deer.  He slid out the heavy box.
to cause something to slip or glide out of something without much effort. The hunter slid his knife out of its sheath and got ready to skin the deer.  He slid out the heavy box.
to cause something to slide or glide into something.  Max slipped the bullets into their chambers and got ready to fire.  He slipped the bullets in silently.
to cause something to slide or glide into something.  Max slipped the bullets into their chambers and got ready to fire.  He slipped the bullets in silently.

dictionary.phrase: slip something over on someone or something
dictionary.definition: to deceive someone. Are you trying to slip something over on me? _ I think he tried to slip one over on me.

dictionary.phrase: slip one over on someone or something
dictionary.definition: to deceive someone. Are you trying to slip something over on me? _ I think he tried to slip one over on me.
to deceive someone. Are you trying to slip something over on me? _ I think he tried to slip one over on me.
to deceive someone. Are you trying to slip something over on me? _ I think he tried to slip one over on me.

dictionary.phrase: slosh something on(to) someone or something
dictionary.definition: to splash or spill a liquid onto someone or something.  Betty sloshed the charcoal lighter f luid on Fred, and he went in to wash it off.  Then she sloshed the f luid onto the charcoal.  Slosh on some more.

to splash or spill a liquid onto someone or something.  Betty sloshed the charcoal lighter f luid on Fred, and he went in to wash it off.  Then she sloshed the f luid onto the charcoal.  Slosh on some more.
very slow-moving. (*Also: as ~.) _ Can’t you get dressed any faster? I declare, you’re as slow as molasses in January.  The traffic on the way to the concert was slower than molasses in January.
very slow-moving. (*Also: as ~.) _ Can’t you get dressed any faster? I declare, you’re as slow as molasses in January.  The traffic on the way to the concert was slower than molasses in January.
slow but unstoppable.  Bob’s progress on his novel was slow but sure.  Nancy is finishing the paint job on her house, slowly but surely.
slow but unstoppable.  Bob’s progress on his novel was slow but sure.  Nancy is finishing the paint job on her house, slowly but surely.
to cause someone or something to reduce speed.  I’m in a hurry. Don’t try to slow me down.  Please slow up the train. There are sheep near the track.
to cause someone or something to reduce speed.  I’m in a hurry. Don’t try to slow me down.  Please slow up the train. There are sheep near the track.
Cliché smart and clever. (*Also: as ~.) _ My nephew is as sly as a fox.  You have to be cunning as a fox to outwit me.
Cliché smart and clever. (*Also: as ~.) _ My nephew is as sly as a fox.  You have to be cunning as a fox to outwit me.
the hours immediately after midnight. The dance went on into the small hours of the night. Jim goes to bed in the wee hours and gets up at lunchtime.
the hours immediately after midnight. The dance went on into the small hours of the night. Jim goes to bed in the wee hours and gets up at lunchtime.

an important part of a document that is not easily noticed because of the smallness of the printing.  You should have read the small print before signing the contract.  You should always read the fine print of an insurance policy.

an important part of a document that is not easily noticed because of the smallness of the printing.  You should have read the small print before signing the contract.  You should always read the fine print of an insurance policy.

dictionary.phrase: smear something on(to) someone or something
dictionary.definition: to spread or rub something onto someone or something. Judy asked Jeff to smear the sun lotion onto her, and he was very happy to do so.  She smeared on the lotion.  Jane smeared a little on.
to spread or rub something onto someone or something. Judy asked Jeff to smear the sun lotion onto her, and he was very happy to do so.  She smeared on the lotion.  Jane smeared a little on.

dictionary.phrase: smoke someone, something, or an animal out of something
dictionary.definition: to force someone, something, or an animal out of something or a place, using smoke.  The police used tear gas to smoke the kidnappers out of the house.  They smoked out the crooks.

dictionary.phrase: smoke someone, something, or an animal out†
dictionary.definition: to force someone, something, or an animal out of something or a place, using smoke.  The police used tear gas to smoke the kidnappers out of the house.  They smoked out the crooks.
Cliché smooth and shiny. (Often used to describe calm bodies of water. *Also: as ~.) _The bay is as smooth as glass, so we should have a pleasant boat trip.  This custard is smooth as silk.
Cliché smooth and shiny. (Often used to describe calm bodies of water. *Also: as ~.) _The bay is as smooth as glass, so we should have a pleasant boat trip.  This custard is smooth as silk.

dictionary.phrase: smooth something onto someone or something
dictionary.definition: to spread or flatten something onto someone or something.  Ted smoothed the suntan lotion onto Alice, who lay on a towel in the sand.  He smoothed on some lotion.
to spread or flatten something onto someone or something.  Ted smoothed the suntan lotion onto Alice, who lay on a towel in the sand.  He smoothed on some lotion.

dictionary.phrase: smuggle someone or something into some place
dictionary.definition: to move someone or something across a border into a place illegally and in secret. The secret agent smuggled his family into the country and then defected.  He smuggled in his family.
to move someone or something across a border into a place illegally and in secret. The secret agent smuggled his family into the country and then defected.  He smuggled in his family.

dictionary.phrase: smuggle someone or something out of some place
dictionary.definition: to move someone or something across a border out of a place illegally and in secret.  Judy smuggled her cousin out of the country in a van.  She smuggled out her cousin.
to move someone or something across a border out of a place illegally and in secret.  Judy smuggled her cousin out of the country in a van.  She smuggled out her cousin.
to put or press something into something with an audible snap.  Next, you snap this little part into this slot here.  Snap in these legs then tighten the screws.
to put or press something into something with an audible snap.  Next, you snap this little part into this slot here.  Snap in these legs then tighten the screws.
to remove something from something, causing an audible snap.  Jeff snapped the plastic plug out of the socket.  He snapped out the plug.
to remove something from something, causing an audible snap.  Jeff snapped the plastic plug out of the socket.  He snapped out the plug.

dictionary.phrase: snatch someone out of the jaws of death
dictionary.definition: to save someone from almost certain or imminent death.  The soldier snatched the tiny child from the jaws of death.

dictionary.phrase: snatch someone from the jaws of death
dictionary.definition: to save someone from almost certain or imminent death.  The soldier snatched the tiny child from the jaws of death.
to cut something off something. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _ She snipped a dead blossom off the rosebush.  Jane snipped off a bud.
to cut something off something. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _ She snipped a dead blossom off the rosebush.  Jane snipped off a bud.

dictionary.phrase: snow someone or something under with something
dictionary.definition: to burden someone or something with something. (Usually too much work.) _The busy season snowed us all under with too much work.  The heavy workload snowed under the office staff.
to burden someone or something with something. (Usually too much work.) _The busy season snowed us all under with too much work.  The heavy workload snowed under the office staff.

dictionary.phrase: so still you could hear a pin drop
dictionary.definition: very quiet. (Also with can.) _When I came into the room, it was so still you could hear a pin drop. Then everyone shouted, “Happy birthday!” _ Please be quiet. Be so quiet you can hear a pin drop.

dictionary.phrase: so quiet you could hear a pin drop
dictionary.definition: very quiet. (Also with can.) _When I came into the room, it was so still you could hear a pin drop. Then everyone shouted, “Happy birthday!” _ Please be quiet. Be so quiet you can hear a pin drop.

to remove something, such as a label or surface soil, from something by soaking in a liquid. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _ She soaked the labels off the bottles and jars.  Please soak off the label.

to remove something, such as a label or surface soil, from something by soaking in a liquid. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _ She soaked the labels off the bottles and jars.  Please soak off the label.
to remove something, such as a stain, from something by soaking in a liquid.  Dan soaked the stain out of his shirt and then washed it.  Dan soaked out the stain.
to remove something, such as a stain, from something by soaking in a liquid.  Dan soaked the stain out of his shirt and then washed it.  Dan soaked out the stain.

Cliché very soft and smooth to the touch. (*Also: as ~.) _ This cloth is as soft as a baby’s bottom.  The kitten’s fur was as soft as down.  Your touch is soft as silk.  This lotion will make your skin soft as velvet.

Cliché very soft and smooth to the touch. (*Also: as ~.) _ This cloth is as soft as a baby’s bottom.  The kitten’s fur was as soft as down.  Your touch is soft as silk.  This lotion will make your skin soft as velvet.

money obtained without much effort.  Don’t become dependent on soft money.  In college he got spoiled by soft money—a check from his parents every week.
money obtained without much effort.  Don’t become dependent on soft money.  In college he got spoiled by soft money—a check from his parents every week.

a firm understanding of something. (*Typically: get ~; have ~; give someone ~.) _ Try to get a grasp of the basic rules.  You don’t have a good grasp of the principles yet.  John was unable to get a solid grasp of the methods used in his work, and we had to let him go.

new personnel; new members brought into a group to revive it. This company needs some new blood on its board to bring in new ideas. We’re trying to get some new blood in the club. Our membership is falling.

new personnel; new members brought into a group to revive it. This company needs some new blood on its board to bring in new ideas. We’re trying to get some new blood in the club. Our membership is falling.

dictionary.phrase: Some people (just) don’t know when to quit.
dictionary.definition: 1. You, or someone being talked about, should stop doing something, such as talking, arguing, scolding, etc. (Often directed toward the person being addressed.) _ Bill: I hate to say it again, but that lipstick is all wrong for you. It brings out the wrong color in your eyes, and it makes your mouth larger than it really is. Jane: Oh, stop, stop! That’s enough! Some people just don’t know when to quit.  John: Those bushes out in the backyard need trimming. Sally: You keep criticizing! Is there no end to it? Some people don’t know when to stop! 2. Some people do not know when to slow down and stop working so hard. Jane: He just kept on gambling. Finally, he had no money left. Sally: Some people don’t know when to quit.

dictionary.phrase: Some people (just) don’t know when to give up.
dictionary.definition: 1. You, or someone being talked about, should stop doing something, such as talking, arguing, scolding, etc. (Often directed toward the person being addressed.) _ Bill: I hate to say it again, but that lipstick is all wrong for you. It brings out the wrong color in your eyes, and it makes your mouth larger than it really is. Jane: Oh, stop, stop! That’s enough! Some people just don’t know when to quit.  John: Those bushes out in the backyard need trimming. Sally: You keep criticizing! Is there no end to it? Some people don’t know when to stop! 2. Some people do not know when to slow down and stop working so hard. Jane: He just kept on gambling. Finally, he had no money left. Sally: Some people don’t know when to quit.

dictionary.phrase: Some people (just) don’t know when to stop.

someone or something great or special. (Old.) _ That chick is some punkins! _ Isn’t this little gadget really some pumpkins?
someone or something great or special. (Old.) _ That chick is some punkins! _ Isn’t this little gadget really some pumpkins?
Euph. someone or some creature is about to die.  The poor old dog’s time has come.  My time has come. I’m ready to go.
Euph. someone or some creature is about to die.  The poor old dog’s time has come.  My time has come. I’m ready to go.
a worthless person. (A substitute for son of a bitch.) _ That tightfisted son of a gun won’t buy me a beer.  He can be a real son of a bachelor when he’s in a bad mood.
a worthless person. (A substitute for son of a bitch.) _ That tightfisted son of a gun won’t buy me a beer.  He can be a real son of a bachelor when he’s in a bad mood.

sorry; whoops. (A gross understatement, said more as a self-deprecating joke than as an apology.) _You spill hot cocoa on my coat, and all you can say is “Sorry ’bout that”? _ When the passenger stepped on my toe, she said, “Sorry about that.”

sorry; whoops. (A gross understatement, said more as a self-deprecating joke than as an apology.) _You spill hot cocoa on my coat, and all you can say is “Sorry ’bout that”? _ When the passenger stepped on my toe, she said, “Sorry about that.”
a sight that one regrets seeing; someone or something that is unpleasant to look at. Well, aren’t you a sorry sight! Go get cleaned up and put on some fresh clothes.
a sight that one regrets seeing; someone or something that is unpleasant to look at. Well, aren’t you a sorry sight! Go get cleaned up and put on some fresh clothes.
to seem, from what has been said, as if something were so. (Sound like is colloquial.) _ It sounds as if you had a good vacation.  You sound like you are angry.
to seem, from what has been said, as if something were so. (Sound like is colloquial.) _ It sounds as if you had a good vacation.  You sound like you are angry.
[for something] not to need explaining; to have an obvious meaning. The facts speak for themselves. Tom is guilty. Your results speak for themselves. You need to work harder.
[for something] not to need explaining; to have an obvious meaning. The facts speak for themselves. Tom is guilty. Your results speak for themselves. You need to work harder.

dictionary.phrase: Speak of the devil (and in he walks).
dictionary.definition: Prov. Talk about a certain person, and that person appears. (Used when someone appears whom you have just been talking about.) _ Alan: I haven’t seen Bob for weeks. Jane: Look, here comes Bob right now. Alan: Well, talk of the devil.  Hi, there. We were just talking about you. Speak of the devil and in he walks.

dictionary.phrase: Talk of the devil (and he is sure to appear).
dictionary.definition: Prov. Talk about a certain person, and that person appears. (Used when someone appears whom you have just been talking about.) _ Alan: I haven’t seen Bob for weeks. Jane: Look, here comes Bob right now. Alan: Well, talk of the devil.  Hi, there. We were just talking about you. Speak of the devil and in he walks.

a transitional phrase announcing that the speaker is going to talk in a more familiar and totally forthright manner. Tom: Speaking quite frankly, I’m not certain she’s the one for the job. Mary: I agree.  Bob: We ought to be looking at housing in a lower price bracket. Bill: Quite frankly, I agree. “Frankly speaking,” said John, “I think you’re out of your mind!”

dictionary.phrase: spend money like it’s going out of style
dictionary.definition: to spend money recklessly; to spend money as if it were worthless or will soon be worthless.  Extravagant? She spends money like it’s going out of style! _I can’t control it. I spend money like there is no tomorrow.

dictionary.phrase: spend money like there’s no tomorrow
dictionary.definition: to spend money recklessly; to spend money as if it were worthless or will soon be worthless.  Extravagant? She spends money like it’s going out of style! _I can’t control it. I spend money like there is no tomorrow.
to be so great in number or volume as to expand into another area. The crowd spilled out into the street. The well-wishers spilled over into the neighbor’s yard.
to be so great in number or volume as to expand into another area. The crowd spilled out into the street. The well-wishers spilled over into the neighbor’s yard.
to give away a secret or a surprise.  There is a surprise party for Heidi on Wednesday. Please don’t spill the beans.  Paul spilled the works about Heidi’s party.
to give away a secret or a surprise.  There is a surprise party for Heidi on Wednesday. Please don’t spill the beans.  Paul spilled the works about Heidi’s party.
to remove liquid from something by spinning.  The washer spun the water out of the load of clothing.  The washer spun out all the water in the clothes.
to remove liquid from something by spinning.  The washer spun the water out of the load of clothing.  The washer spun out all the water in the clothes.

the very likeness of someone; a very close resemblence to someone. (*The second version is a frequent error. *Typically: be ~; look like ~.) _John is the spit and image of his father.  At first, I thought you were saying spitting image.

the very likeness of someone; a very close resemblence to someone. (*The second version is a frequent error. *Typically: be ~; look like ~.) _John is the spit and image of his father.  At first, I thought you were saying spitting image.
to expel something from the mouth into something.  He spit his gum into the toilet.  He opened the toilet and spit in his gum.
to expel something from the mouth into something.  He spit his gum into the toilet.  He opened the toilet and spit in his gum.

1. to move about in a volume of a liquid, splashing.  The children splashed about in the pool.  They splashed around for an hour. 2. [for a liquid] to move about, splashing.  The water splashed about in the bucket. It splashed around as I carried the bucket.

1. to move about in a volume of a liquid, splashing.  The children splashed about in the pool.  They splashed around for an hour. 2. [for a liquid] to move about, splashing.  The water splashed about in the bucket. It splashed around as I carried the bucket.

[for a bit of something] to tear off or separate from something. (Of is usually retained before pronouns.) _A piece of wood splintered off of the oar and dropped into the water. A tiny bit splintered off and stuck in my hand.

1. Fig. Inf. to laugh very hard. He laughed until he nearly split a gut. The clown made me bust a gut laughing. 2. Fig. Inf. to work very hard.  I split a gut to get this place fixed up in a week.  Don’t bust a gut cleaning up for me. I love things that are a bit messy.
